nodes.label: Understanding variables as unknowns
nodes.title: Recognizing that letters like x, y, a represent unknown numbers that can change or be solved for.

nodes.label: Understanding coefficients
nodes.title: Recognizing that numbers in front of variables (like 3 in 3x) multiply the variable.

nodes.label: Understanding constant terms
nodes.title: Recognizing numbers without variables (like +5 or -7) as constant terms that don't change.

nodes.label: Identifying terms in expressions
nodes.title: Breaking down expressions into separate terms separated by + or - signs.

nodes.label: Recognizing like terms
nodes.title: Identifying terms with the same variable and same power that can be combined (e.g., 3x and 5x).

nodes.label: Combining like terms
nodes.title: Adding or subtracting coefficients of like terms while keeping the variable part unchanged.

nodes.label: Understanding distributive property
nodes.title: Recognizing that a(b + c) = ab + ac - multiplying outside brackets affects everything inside.

nodes.label: Expanding single brackets
nodes.title: Multiplying a number or variable outside brackets by everything inside: 3(x + 2) = 3x + 6.

nodes.label: Expanding with negative signs
nodes.title: Understanding that -(x + 3) = -x - 3 and multiplying by negative numbers changes all signs.

nodes.label: FOIL method for binomials
nodes.title: Multiplying (a+b)(c+d) by multiplying First, Outer, Inner, Last terms systematically.

nodes.label: Expanding double brackets
nodes.title: Multiplying two bracketed expressions by ensuring every term in first bracket multiplies every term in second.

nodes.label: Collecting terms after expansion
nodes.title: Simplifying expanded expressions by combining like terms to get final simplified form.

nodes.label: Recognizing common factors
nodes.title: Identifying the highest common factor that can be taken out of all terms in an expression.

nodes.label: Factoring out numerical common factors
nodes.title: Taking out the largest number that divides all coefficients: 6x + 9 = 3(2x + 3).

nodes.label: Factoring out variable common factors
nodes.title: Taking out the highest power of variables common to all terms: x² + x³ = x²(1 + x).

nodes.label: Factoring out mixed common factors
nodes.title: Taking out both numerical and variable factors: 4x²y + 6xy² = 2xy(2x + 3y).

nodes.label: Factoring by grouping
nodes.title: Grouping terms in fours and factoring each pair before factoring the resulting expression.

nodes.label: Recognizing difference of two squares
nodes.title: Identifying expressions of the form a² - b² that can be factored as (a-b)(a+b).

nodes.label: Factoring difference of two squares
nodes.title: Converting a² - b² into factored form (a - b)(a + b).

nodes.label: Recognizing perfect square trinomials
nodes.title: Identifying trinomials of the form a² ± 2ab + b² that factor as (a ± b)².

nodes.label: Factoring perfect square trinomials
nodes.title: Converting a² + 2ab + b² = (a + b)² or a² - 2ab + b² = (a - b)².

nodes.label: Factoring x² + bx + c
nodes.title: Finding two numbers that multiply to c and add to b to factor as (x + p)(x + q).

nodes.label: Factoring ax² + bx + c (a ≠ 1)
nodes.title: Using ac-method or trial and error to factor quadratics where leading coefficient is not 1.

nodes.label: Trial and error for factoring quadratics
nodes.title: Systematically testing factor combinations for ax² + bx + c until correct factorization is found.

nodes.label: AC method for factoring quadratics
nodes.title: Finding factors of ac that add to b, then grouping terms to factor ax² + bx + c.

nodes.label: Understanding algebraic fractions
nodes.title: Recognizing fractions where numerator and/or denominator contain variables.

nodes.label: Canceling common factors in fractions
nodes.title: Dividing both numerator and denominator by common factors to simplify fractions.

nodes.label: Simplifying algebraic fractions
nodes.title: Factoring numerator and denominator then canceling common factors to lowest terms.

nodes.label: Multiplying algebraic fractions
nodes.title: Multiplying numerators together and denominators together: (a/b) × (c/d) = (ac)/(bd).

nodes.label: Dividing algebraic fractions
nodes.title: Multiplying by the reciprocal: (a/b) ÷ (c/d) = (a/b) × (d/c) = (ad)/(bc).

nodes.label: Finding common denominators for algebraic fractions
nodes.title: Finding the least common multiple of denominators to add or subtract fractions.

nodes.label: Adding fractions with same denominator
nodes.title: Adding numerators while keeping denominator the same: a/c + b/c = (a+b)/c.

nodes.label: Adding fractions with different denominators
nodes.title: Converting to common denominator then adding numerators.

nodes.label: Understanding what an equation is
nodes.title: Recognizing equations as mathematical statements saying two expressions are equal (using = sign).

nodes.label: Understanding what a solution is
nodes.title: Recognizing that a solution is a value that makes the equation true when substituted.

nodes.label: Understanding inverse operations
nodes.title: Knowing that addition/subtraction and multiplication/division are opposite operations that undo each other.

nodes.label: Balance method for equations
nodes.title: Understanding that what you do to one side of equation, you must do to the other side.

nodes.label: Solving one-step linear equations
nodes.title: Solving equations like x + 3 = 7 or 2x = 10 using single inverse operation.

nodes.label: Solving two-step linear equations
nodes.title: Solving equations like 2x + 3 = 11 by using two inverse operations in correct order.

nodes.label: Solving multi-step linear equations
nodes.title: Solving complex linear equations by combining like terms and using multiple operations.

nodes.label: Linear equations with variables on both sides
nodes.title: Solving equations like 3x + 2 = x + 8 by collecting variables on one side.

nodes.label: Linear equations with brackets
nodes.title: Expanding brackets first, then solving: 3(x + 2) = 15 becomes 3x + 6 = 15.

nodes.label: Clearing fractions in equations
nodes.title: Multiplying all terms by LCD to eliminate fractions before solving.

nodes.label: Linear equations with fractions
nodes.title: Solving equations containing fractions by clearing denominators or finding common denominators.

nodes.label: Checking solutions to linear equations
nodes.title: Substituting solution back into original equation to verify it makes both sides equal.

nodes.label: Identifying no solution vs infinite solutions
nodes.title: Recognizing when solving leads to contradictions (no solution) or identities (infinite solutions).

nodes.label: Understanding simultaneous equations
nodes.title: Recognizing that we need to find values that satisfy both equations at the same time.

nodes.label: Substitution method concept
nodes.title: Understanding that we can replace one variable with an expression from the other equation.

nodes.label: Substitution method steps
nodes.title: 1) Make one variable the subject 2) Substitute into other equation 3) Solve 4) Find second variable.

nodes.label: Elimination method concept
nodes.title: Understanding that we can add or subtract equations to eliminate one variable.

nodes.label: Elimination with same coefficients
nodes.title: When coefficients of a variable are the same or opposites, directly add or subtract equations.

nodes.label: Elimination with different coefficients
nodes.title: Multiplying one or both equations to make coefficients the same, then eliminating.

nodes.label: Elimination method complete process
nodes.title: Systematic process of making coefficients equal, eliminating, solving, then substituting back.

nodes.label: Graphical solution of simultaneous equations
nodes.title: Finding intersection point of two lines as the solution to the system.

nodes.label: Recognizing parallel lines (no solution)
nodes.title: When simultaneous equations represent parallel lines, there is no intersection point.

nodes.label: Recognizing same line (infinite solutions)
nodes.title: When simultaneous equations represent the same line, every point is a solution.

nodes.label: Standard form of quadratic equation
nodes.title: Recognizing ax² + bx + c = 0 as standard form where a ≠ 0.

nodes.label: Identifying quadratic equations
nodes.title: Recognizing equations with x² as highest power, distinguishing from linear equations.

nodes.label: Rearranging to standard form
nodes.title: Moving all terms to one side to get ax² + bx + c = 0 form.

nodes.label: Zero product property
nodes.title: Understanding that if AB = 0, then A = 0 or B = 0 (or both).

nodes.label: Solving quadratics by factoring
nodes.title: Factor the quadratic, then use zero product property to find solutions.

nodes.label: Applying zero product property after factoring
nodes.title: Setting each factor equal to zero and solving the resulting linear equations.

nodes.label: Why we complete the square
nodes.title: Understanding that we want to create a perfect square to take square roots.

nodes.label: Completing square for x² + bx
nodes.title: Adding (b/2)² to make x² + bx + (b/2)² = (x + b/2)².

nodes.label: Step-by-step completing the square
nodes.title: 1) Move constant to right 2) Add (b/2)² to both sides 3) Factor left side 4) Take square root.

nodes.label: Completing the square method
nodes.title: Complete systematic method for solving quadratics by creating perfect square trinomials.

nodes.label: Taking square root of both sides
nodes.title: Understanding that √(x²) = ±x, so we get two solutions from taking square roots.

nodes.label: Understanding quadratic formula components
nodes.title: Identifying a, b, c in ax² + bx + c = 0 and understanding the formula structure.

nodes.label: Quadratic formula
nodes.title: x = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac)) / (2a) for solving any quadratic equation.

nodes.label: Substituting values into quadratic formula
nodes.title: Carefully substituting a, b, c values, paying attention to negative signs.

nodes.label: Simplifying quadratic formula results
nodes.title: Simplifying radicals and fractions in the final answer.

nodes.label: Understanding the discriminant
nodes.title: Recognizing b² - 4ac as the discriminant that determines nature of roots.

nodes.label: Discriminant of a quadratic equation
nodes.title: Calculating b² - 4ac to determine the nature of the roots.

nodes.label: Discriminant > 0: two real roots
nodes.title: When b² - 4ac > 0, the quadratic has two distinct real solutions.

nodes.label: Discriminant = 0: one repeated root
nodes.title: When b² - 4ac = 0, the quadratic has one repeated real solution.

nodes.label: Discriminant < 0: no real roots
nodes.title: When b² - 4ac < 0, the quadratic has no real solutions (complex solutions).

nodes.label: Nature of quadratic roots
nodes.title: Using discriminant to predict the type and number of solutions before solving.

nodes.label: Sum and product of quadratic roots
nodes.title: For ax² + bx + c = 0: sum = -b/a, product = c/a.

nodes.label: Forming quadratic from given roots
nodes.title: If roots are p and q, then equation is (x - p)(x - q) = 0.

nodes.label: Expanding (x - p)(x - q) form
nodes.title: Expanding factored form to get standard form ax² + bx + c = 0.

nodes.label: Understanding coordinate system
nodes.title: Understanding x-axis (horizontal), y-axis (vertical), and ordered pairs (x, y).

nodes.label: Plotting points on coordinate plane
nodes.title: Locating and marking points using x and y coordinates.

nodes.label: Identifying linear vs non-linear relationships
nodes.title: Recognizing that linear relationships form straight lines when graphed.

nodes.label: Understanding slope as rate of change
nodes.title: Recognizing slope as how much y changes for each unit change in x.

nodes.label: Slope as rise over run
nodes.title: Calculating slope as vertical change divided by horizontal change.

nodes.label: Finding slope from two points
nodes.title: Using m = (y₂ - y₁)/(x₂ - x₁) to calculate slope from coordinates.

nodes.label: Understanding positive slope
nodes.title: Recognizing that positive slope means line goes up from left to right.

nodes.label: Understanding negative slope
nodes.title: Recognizing that negative slope means line goes down from left to right.

nodes.label: Zero slope for horizontal lines
nodes.title: Understanding that horizontal lines have slope = 0 and equation y = constant.

nodes.label: Undefined slope for vertical lines
nodes.title: Understanding that vertical lines have undefined slope and equation x = constant.

nodes.label: Understanding y-intercept
nodes.title: Recognizing y-intercept as where line crosses y-axis (when x = 0).

nodes.label: Understanding x-intercept
nodes.title: Recognizing x-intercept as where line crosses x-axis (when y = 0).

nodes.label: Slope-intercept form y = mx + c
nodes.title: Understanding that m is slope and c is y-intercept in this form.

nodes.label: Graphing lines using slope-intercept form
nodes.title: Starting at y-intercept and using slope to find additional points.

nodes.label: Understanding point-slope form
nodes.title: Using y - y₁ = m(x - x₁) when given a point and slope.

nodes.label: Finding equation from point and slope
nodes.title: Using point-slope form then converting to slope-intercept form.

nodes.label: Finding equation from two points
nodes.title: Finding slope first, then using point-slope form with either point.

nodes.label: General form ax + by + c = 0
nodes.title: Understanding standard form of linear equation where A, B, C are integers.

nodes.label: Converting between forms of linear equations
nodes.title: Converting between slope-intercept, point-slope, and general forms.

nodes.label: Parallel lines have same slope
nodes.title: Understanding that parallel lines never intersect and have equal slopes.

nodes.label: Perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slopes
nodes.title: Understanding that if m₁ × m₂ = -1, then lines are perpendicular.

nodes.label: Finding parallel and perpendicular line equations
nodes.title: Using slope relationships to find equations of parallel or perpendicular lines.

nodes.label: Recognizing parabola shape
nodes.title: Understanding that quadratic functions create U-shaped or upside-down U curves.

nodes.label: Direction of parabola opening
nodes.title: If a > 0, parabola opens upward; if a < 0, parabola opens downward.

nodes.label: Quadratic function vs equation
nodes.title: Understanding difference between y = ax² + bx + c (function) and ax² + bx + c = 0 (equation).

nodes.label: Understanding vertex as turning point
nodes.title: Recognizing vertex as the highest or lowest point on the parabola.

nodes.label: Vertex coordinates
nodes.title: Finding vertex using x = -b/(2a), then substituting to find y-coordinate.

nodes.label: Vertex form y = a(x - h)² + k
nodes.title: Understanding that vertex is at (h, k) in this form.

nodes.label: Converting to vertex form by completing square
nodes.title: Using completing the square to rewrite in vertex form.

nodes.label: Minimum point identification
nodes.title: Recognizing minimum occurs when a > 0 (parabola opens upward).

nodes.label: Maximum point identification
nodes.title: Recognizing maximum occurs when a < 0 (parabola opens downward).

nodes.label: Axis of symmetry
nodes.title: Understanding that parabola is symmetric about vertical line x = -b/(2a).

nodes.label: Y-intercept of quadratic
nodes.title: Finding y-intercept by setting x = 0, giving y = c.

nodes.label: X-intercepts of quadratic
nodes.title: Finding x-intercepts by solving ax² + bx + c = 0.

nodes.label: Relationship between intercepts and roots
nodes.title: Understanding that x-intercepts of y = ax² + bx + c are the roots of ax² + bx + c = 0.

nodes.label: Sketching parabola using key points
nodes.title: Using vertex, intercepts, and axis of symmetry to sketch accurate parabola.

nodes.label: Domain and range of quadratic functions
nodes.title: Domain: all real numbers; Range: depends on vertex and direction of opening.

nodes.label: Creating table of values for parabola
nodes.title: Choosing x-values around vertex to create systematic table for graphing.

nodes.label: Using symmetry when graphing parabolas
nodes.title: Using axis of symmetry to find corresponding points on either side of vertex.

nodes.label: Inequality symbols and meaning
nodes.title: Understanding <, >, ≤, ≥ symbols and their meanings in mathematical expressions.

nodes.label: Difference between inequalities and equations
nodes.title: Understanding that inequalities show ranges of values, not exact values.

nodes.label: Understanding solution sets
nodes.title: Recognizing that inequalities have many solutions, often expressed as intervals.

nodes.label: Representing inequalities on number line
nodes.title: Using open/closed circles and arrows to show solution sets on number line.

nodes.label: Interval notation for inequalities
nodes.title: Writing solution sets using interval notation like [a, b) or (-∞, c].

nodes.label: Adding/subtracting same number to inequalities
nodes.title: Understanding that adding or subtracting same number preserves inequality direction.

nodes.label: Multiplying/dividing by positive numbers
nodes.title: Understanding that multiplying/dividing by positive numbers preserves inequality direction.

nodes.label: Multiplying/dividing by negative numbers
nodes.title: Understanding that multiplying/dividing by negative numbers reverses inequality direction.

nodes.label: Complete rules for manipulating inequalities
nodes.title: All rules for adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing inequalities.

nodes.label: Solving one-step inequalities
nodes.title: Solving inequalities like x + 3 > 7 or 2x ≤ 10 using single operations.

nodes.label: Solving two-step inequalities
nodes.title: Solving inequalities like 2x + 3 < 11 using multiple operations.

nodes.label: Multi-step linear inequalities
nodes.title: Solving complex linear inequalities with variables on both sides.

nodes.label: Compound inequalities with 'and'
nodes.title: Solving inequalities like -3 < 2x + 1 < 7 (intersection of conditions).

nodes.label: Compound inequalities with 'or'
nodes.title: Solving inequalities like x < -2 or x > 5 (union of conditions).

nodes.label: Graphing compound inequalities
nodes.title: Representing and/or compound inequalities on number lines.

nodes.label: Understanding quadratic inequalities
nodes.title: Recognizing inequalities involving quadratic expressions like x² + 3x - 4 > 0.

nodes.label: Finding critical points
nodes.title: Finding where quadratic expression equals zero (the boundary points).

nodes.label: Sign chart method for quadratic inequalities
nodes.title: Testing sign of expression in each interval between critical points.

nodes.label: Solving quadratic inequalities completely
nodes.title: Complete process: factor, find critical points, test intervals, write solution.

nodes.label: Interpreting inequalities graphically
nodes.title: Understanding that y > f(x) means points above the graph.

nodes.label: Using graphs to solve inequalities
nodes.title: Reading solution sets from graphs by identifying relevant regions.

nodes.label: Understanding what a sequence is
nodes.title: Recognizing sequences as ordered lists of numbers following a pattern.

nodes.label: Understanding term and position
nodes.title: Recognizing that each number in sequence has a position (1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.).

nodes.label: Recognizing arithmetic sequences
nodes.title: Identifying sequences where consecutive terms have constant difference.

nodes.label: Finding common difference
nodes.title: Calculating d by subtracting consecutive terms: d = a₂ - a₁.

nodes.label: Understanding arithmetic sequences
nodes.title: Recognizing pattern and structure of arithmetic sequences.

nodes.label: First term notation a₁
nodes.title: Understanding that a₁ (or a) represents the first term of the sequence.

nodes.label: nth term formula for arithmetic sequences
nodes.title: Using aₙ = a₁ + (n-1)d to find any term in arithmetic sequence.

nodes.label: Finding specific terms in arithmetic sequences
nodes.title: Using nth term formula to find particular terms like 10th term, 25th term.

nodes.label: Finding position when given term value
nodes.title: Using nth term formula to find which position has a given value.

nodes.label: Understanding difference between series and sequence
nodes.title: Sequence is list of terms; series is sum of terms.

nodes.label: Arithmetic series concept
nodes.title: Understanding arithmetic series as sum of arithmetic sequence terms.

nodes.label: Partial sum notation Sₙ
nodes.title: Understanding that Sₙ represents sum of first n terms.

nodes.label: Sum formula for arithmetic series
nodes.title: Using Sₙ = n/2[2a + (n-1)d] or Sₙ = n/2(first + last).

nodes.label: Choosing appropriate sum formula
nodes.title: Use Sₙ = n/2[2a + (n-1)d] when given a and d; use Sₙ = n/2(first + last) when given endpoints.

nodes.label: Recognizing geometric sequences
nodes.title: Identifying sequences where consecutive terms have constant ratio.

nodes.label: Finding common ratio
nodes.title: Calculating r by dividing consecutive terms: r = a₂/a₁.

nodes.label: Understanding geometric sequences
nodes.title: Recognizing pattern and structure of geometric sequences.

nodes.label: nth term formula for geometric sequences
nodes.title: Using aₙ = a₁ × r^(n-1) to find any term in geometric sequence.

nodes.label: Understanding geometric growth and decay
nodes.title: Recognizing that r > 1 gives growth, 0 < r < 1 gives decay.

nodes.label: Geometric series concept
nodes.title: Understanding geometric series as sum of geometric sequence terms.

nodes.label: Sum of finite geometric series
nodes.title: Using Sₙ = a(rⁿ - 1)/(r - 1) when r ≠ 1.

nodes.label: Understanding convergent series
nodes.title: Recognizing when infinite geometric series has finite sum (when |r| < 1).

nodes.label: Sum of infinite geometric series
nodes.title: Using S = a/(1 - r) when |r| < 1 for infinite geometric series.

nodes.label: Understanding exponential functions
nodes.title: Recognizing functions of the form y = aˣ where base is constant, exponent is variable.

nodes.label: Exponential vs polynomial functions
nodes.title: Understanding difference between aˣ (exponential) and xᵃ (polynomial).

nodes.label: Exponential equations with same base
nodes.title: Solving aˣ = aʸ by equating exponents: x = y.

nodes.label: Steps for same-base exponential equations
nodes.title: 1) Express both sides with same base 2) Equate exponents 3) Solve resulting equation.

nodes.label: More complex exponential equations
nodes.title: Solving exponential equations that require factoring or substitution.

nodes.label: Logarithm as inverse of exponential
nodes.title: Understanding that log and exponential functions undo each other.

nodes.label: Definition of logarithm
nodes.title: Understanding that log_a(x) = y means aʸ = x.

nodes.label: Logarithmic function notation
nodes.title: Understanding notation log_a(x) and special cases log(x) = log₁₀(x), ln(x) = log_e(x).

nodes.label: Converting between exponential and logarithmic form
nodes.title: Converting aʸ = x to y = log_a(x) and vice versa.

nodes.label: Logarithm product rule
nodes.title: Understanding that log(xy) = log(x) + log(y).

nodes.label: Logarithm quotient rule
nodes.title: Understanding that log(x/y) = log(x) - log(y).

nodes.label: Logarithm power rule
nodes.title: Understanding that log(xⁿ) = n·log(x).

nodes.label: All laws of logarithms
nodes.title: Complete set of logarithm rules for products, quotients, and powers.

nodes.label: Expanding logarithmic expressions
nodes.title: Using logarithm rules to expand expressions like log(x²y/z).

nodes.label: Condensing logarithmic expressions
nodes.title: Combining multiple logarithms into single logarithm using rules.

nodes.label: Basic logarithmic equations
nodes.title: Solving equations like log(x) = 3 by converting to exponential form.

nodes.label: Logarithmic equations with same base
nodes.title: Solving log_a(x) = log_a(y) by equating arguments: x = y.

nodes.label: Change of base formula
nodes.title: Converting log_a(x) = log_b(x)/log_b(a) to use calculator-friendly bases.

nodes.label: Understanding absolute value
nodes.title: Understanding |x| as distance from zero, always non-negative.

nodes.label: Absolute value definition
nodes.title: Understanding |x| = x when x ≥ 0, and |x| = -x when x < 0.

nodes.label: Modulus function properties
nodes.title: Understanding properties like |xy| = |x||y| and |x/y| = |x|/|y|.

nodes.label: Simple absolute value equations
nodes.title: Solving |x| = a by considering x = a or x = -a (when a ≥ 0).

nodes.label: Basic modulus equations
nodes.title: Solving |ax + b| = c by considering both positive and negative cases.

nodes.label: Complex modulus equations
nodes.title: Solving equations with multiple absolute value expressions.

nodes.label: Absolute value inequalities
nodes.title: Solving |x| < a (gives -a < x < a) and |x| > a (gives x < -a or x > a).

nodes.label: Checking solutions in absolute value equations
nodes.title: Verifying solutions by substituting back into original equation.

nodes.label: Recognizing when expression is algebraic
nodes.title: Distinguishing algebraic expressions from arithmetic expressions by presence of variables.

nodes.label: Systematic term counting technique
nodes.title: Looking for + and - signs to separate terms, remembering first term might not have visible sign.

nodes.label: Recognizing implicit coefficients
nodes.title: Understanding that x means 1x and -x means -1x (coefficient of 1 is usually hidden).

nodes.label: Recognizing implied exponents
nodes.title: Understanding that x means x¹ (exponent of 1 is usually hidden).

nodes.label: Finding degree of individual terms
nodes.title: Adding exponents of all variables in a term to find its degree.

nodes.label: Identifying leading term
nodes.title: Finding the term with highest degree (usually written first in standard form).

nodes.label: Arranging polynomials in standard form
nodes.title: Writing terms in descending order of degree (highest power first).

nodes.label: Recognizing missing terms in polynomials
nodes.title: Understanding that x³ + 5x + 2 is missing the x² term (coefficient is 0).

nodes.label: Recognizing like terms with multiple variables
nodes.title: Understanding that 3xy and -7xy are like terms, but 3xy and 3x²y are not.

nodes.label: Handling signs when combining like terms
nodes.title: Technique: treat the sign as part of the coefficient (3x + (-5x) = -2x).

nodes.label: Visual technique for distributive property
nodes.title: Drawing arrows from outside term to each inside term to ensure nothing is missed.

nodes.label: Distributive property with variables outside
nodes.title: Applying distributive law when variable is outside: x(y + 3) = xy + 3x.

nodes.label: Double negative rule in expansion
nodes.title: Understanding that -(-x) = +x when expanding negative brackets.

nodes.label: Common mistakes in bracket expansion
nodes.title: Avoiding errors like 2(x + 3) = 2x + 3 (forgetting to multiply second term).

nodes.label: Physical finger technique for FOIL
nodes.title: Using fingers to point to terms being multiplied to avoid missing combinations.

nodes.label: Organizing FOIL calculations
nodes.title: Writing F, O, I, L labels to systematically track which terms have been multiplied.

nodes.label: Recognizing special products before expanding
nodes.title: Checking if expression is (a+b)², (a-b)², or (a+b)(a-b) before using FOIL.

nodes.label: Collecting middle terms in quadratic expansion
nodes.title: Combining the O and I terms from FOIL to get the bx term in ax² + bx + c.

nodes.label: Perfect square expansion shortcuts
nodes.title: Using (a±b)² = a² ± 2ab + b² instead of FOIL for faster expansion.

nodes.label: GCF inspection technique
nodes.title: Looking at each term to find largest number and highest variable power that divides all.

nodes.label: Checking factoring by distributing back
nodes.title: Multiplying factored form back out to verify it equals original expression.

nodes.label: Strategic grouping for factoring by grouping
nodes.title: Grouping first two and last two terms, or trying different groupings if first doesn't work.

nodes.label: Finding GCF within each group
nodes.title: Taking out common factors from each group separately before looking for common binomial.

nodes.label: Recognizing common binomial factor
nodes.title: Identifying when both groups have the same binomial factor after initial factoring.

nodes.label: Visual pattern recognition for difference of squares
nodes.title: Looking for 'something squared minus something else squared' pattern.

nodes.label: Pattern recognition for perfect square trinomials
nodes.title: Checking if first and last terms are perfect squares and middle term is twice their product.

nodes.label: Middle term check for perfect squares
nodes.title: Verifying that middle coefficient equals 2√(first term × last term).

nodes.label: Listing factor pairs systematically
nodes.title: Writing all factor pairs of c, then checking which pair adds to b.

nodes.label: Sign analysis for quadratic factoring
nodes.title: If c > 0, factors have same sign as b; if c < 0, factors have opposite signs.

nodes.label: AC method: multiply a and c
nodes.title: First step of AC method - calculate the product a×c.

nodes.label: AC method: find factor pairs of ac
nodes.title: List all factor pairs of ac that multiply to give ac.

nodes.label: AC method: check which pair sums to b
nodes.title: Test each factor pair to see which adds up to the middle coefficient b.

nodes.label: AC method: split middle term
nodes.title: Rewrite bx as the sum of the two factors found, creating four terms.

nodes.label: AC method: group and factor
nodes.title: Group the four terms in pairs and factor by grouping.

nodes.label: Systematic trial and error for factoring
nodes.title: Testing factor combinations in organized way rather than random guessing.

nodes.label: Identifying domain restrictions for fractions
nodes.title: Finding values that make denominator zero (these values are excluded from domain).

nodes.label: Always factor before canceling
nodes.title: Factoring numerator and denominator completely before looking for common factors to cancel.

nodes.label: Canceling factors, not terms
nodes.title: Understanding that only multiplied factors can be canceled, not added/subtracted terms.

nodes.label: Cross multiplication for algebraic fractions
nodes.title: Using cross multiplication when dividing fractions: (a/b) ÷ (c/d) = (a/b) × (d/c).

nodes.label: Finding LCD for algebraic expressions
nodes.title: Taking highest power of each factor that appears in any denominator.

nodes.label: Converting to common denominator technique
nodes.title: Multiplying numerator and denominator by missing factors to achieve LCD.

nodes.label: Identifying main fraction bar in complex fractions
nodes.title: Recognizing which fraction bar represents the main division in complex fractions.

nodes.label: Distinguishing equations from expressions
nodes.title: Equations have equals signs and can be solved; expressions are simplified or evaluated.

nodes.label: Understanding 'isolating the variable'
nodes.title: Getting the variable by itself on one side of the equation.

nodes.label: Order for undoing operations
nodes.title: Undoing operations in reverse order of operations (PEMDAS backwards).

nodes.label: Maintaining equation balance technique
nodes.title: Always performing the same operation on both sides to keep equation true.

nodes.label: Recognizing when coefficient is 1
nodes.title: Understanding when variable is isolated (coefficient = 1) vs. when more work is needed.

nodes.label: Clearing fraction coefficients
nodes.title: Multiplying both sides by reciprocal to eliminate fraction coefficient of variable.

nodes.label: Combining like terms within equations
nodes.title: Simplifying each side of equation before attempting to isolate variable.

nodes.label: Moving all variables to one side
nodes.title: Adding or subtracting variable terms to collect them on one side of equation.

nodes.label: Moving constants to opposite side
nodes.title: Adding or subtracting constant terms to move them away from variables.

nodes.label: Expanding brackets as first step in equations
nodes.title: Using distributive property before attempting to solve equation.

nodes.label: Clearing fractions by multiplying by LCD
nodes.title: Multiplying every term by LCD to eliminate all fractions at once.

nodes.label: Substitution technique for checking
nodes.title: Replacing variable with solution value in original equation to verify both sides equal.

nodes.label: Recognizing no solution situations
nodes.title: Identifying contradictions like 5 = 7 that indicate no solution exists.

nodes.label: Recognizing infinite solution situations
nodes.title: Identifying identities like 3 = 3 that indicate all values are solutions.

nodes.label: Visual interpretation of simultaneous equations
nodes.title: Understanding that solution is where two lines intersect on a graph.

nodes.label: Choosing between substitution and elimination
nodes.title: Using substitution when one variable has coefficient 1; elimination when coefficients are multiples.

nodes.label: Making the substitution in substitution method
nodes.title: Carefully replacing every instance of chosen variable with the expression.

nodes.label: Making coefficients match for elimination
nodes.title: Multiplying equations by appropriate numbers to make coefficients opposites or equal.

nodes.label: Choosing addition vs subtraction in elimination
nodes.title: Adding equations when coefficients are opposites; subtracting when coefficients are equal.

nodes.label: Back-substitution technique
nodes.title: Using found value of one variable to find the other variable.

nodes.label: Verifying simultaneous equation solutions
nodes.title: Checking that solution pair satisfies both original equations.

nodes.label: Reading intersection coordinates from graph
nodes.title: Accurately determining x and y coordinates where two lines cross.

nodes.label: Systematic error checking techniques
nodes.title: Double-checking work by using different methods or working backwards.

nodes.label: Awareness of common algebraic mistakes
nodes.title: Watching for errors like (x + y)² ≠ x² + y² and x/(x + y) ≠ 1/y.

nodes.label: Preventing sign errors
nodes.title: Extra care with negative signs, using parentheses, and double-checking sign changes.

nodes.label: Preventing fraction errors
nodes.title: Being careful with fraction operations and always checking if simplification is possible.

edges.title: Students must understand that variables represent unknown values before they can recognize coefficients as the numbers that multiply those variables.
Understanding coefficients is essential before students can break down expressions into separate terms for analysis.
Students must be able to identify individual terms before they can recognize which terms have the same variable parts.
Recognizing like terms is prerequisite to combining them by adding or subtracting their coefficients.
Understanding the distributive property concept is necessary before applying it to expand single brackets.
Students must master basic bracket expansion before handling the complexity of negative signs in expansion.
Understanding negative sign distribution prepares students for the systematic FOIL method with binomials.
FOIL method provides the systematic foundation needed for expanding any double bracket expressions.
Students must know how to expand brackets before they can simplify the resulting expressions by collecting like terms.
Recognizing common factors is essential before students can apply the technique of factoring out numerical common factors.
Understanding numerical factoring provides the foundation for recognizing and factoring out variable common factors.
Students need experience with both numerical and variable factoring before combining them in mixed common factors.
Mastery of basic factoring techniques is required before attempting the more complex factoring by grouping method.
Students must recognize the difference of squares pattern before they can apply the factoring formula (a-b)(a+b).
Pattern recognition for perfect square trinomials must come before applying the factoring technique (a±b)².
Students must master factoring simple quadratics (a=1) before tackling complex quadratics where a≠1.
Understanding general quadratic factoring provides the foundation for systematic trial and error approaches.
Students need to understand the goal of quadratic factoring before learning the systematic AC method approach.
Understanding what an equation is must precede recognizing what constitutes a solution to that equation.
Understanding solutions requires knowing inverse operations to systematically undo equation operations.
Knowledge of inverse operations is essential for understanding the balance method of maintaining equation equality.
Understanding equation balance is prerequisite to solving even the simplest one-step linear equations.
One-step equation solving skills are essential building blocks for tackling two-step linear equations.
Two-step solving techniques provide the foundation for handling more complex multi-step linear equations.
Multi-step equation skills are required before students can handle variables appearing on both sides.
Students must understand bracket expansion before they can solve equations containing brackets.
Understanding standard form structure is essential for recognizing different types of quadratic equations.
Students must identify quadratic equations before they can rearrange them into standard form.
Having equations in standard form is necessary before applying the zero product property.
Understanding zero product property is essential before using factoring methods to solve quadratics.
Students need factoring skills before they can apply zero product property to each factor.
Understanding why we complete the square is essential before learning the specific technique.
Students must understand the basic completing square pattern before following the complete step-by-step method.
Completing the square method must be mastered before students can take square roots to find solutions.
Students must understand formula components (a,b,c) before they can apply the quadratic formula.
Understanding the quadratic formula structure is required before carefully substituting specific values.
Students must be able to substitute into the formula before they can simplify the resulting expressions.
Understanding discriminant concept is prerequisite to calculating b²-4ac for specific equations.
Students must know how to calculate the discriminant before interpreting positive discriminant results.
Discriminant calculation ability is required before recognizing the zero discriminant case.
Students need discriminant calculation skills before understanding negative discriminant implications.
Point plotting experience is necessary before students can identify linear versus non-linear patterns.
Recognizing linear relationships provides the foundation for understanding slope as rate of change.
Understanding slope concept is prerequisite to calculating slope using rise over run.
Rise over run concept is essential before students can find slope from two specific points.
Students must be able to calculate slope before they can interpret positive slope direction.
Slope calculation skills are required before students can recognize negative slope patterns.
Understanding y-intercept concept is essential before learning slope-intercept form where it appears as 'c'.
Students must understand slope before learning slope-intercept form where slope appears as 'm'.
Understanding slope-intercept form provides the foundation for graphing lines using this method.
Students need slope-intercept form knowledge before understanding the alternative point-slope form.
Understanding point-slope form is essential for finding equations when given a point and slope.
Finding equations from point and slope provides foundation for the more complex two-point method.
Understanding parallel line relationships is prerequisite for finding equations of parallel lines.
Understanding perpendicular slope relationships is essential before finding perpendicular line equations.
Students must recognize parabola shape before they can determine which direction it opens.
Understanding opening direction helps students recognize the vertex as the turning point.
Understanding vertex concept is prerequisite to learning the specific coordinate calculation method.
Students need vertex coordinate skills before understanding vertex form where (h,k) represents the vertex.
Finding vertex coordinates provides the foundation for understanding the axis of symmetry.
Understanding parabola opening direction is essential for identifying when the vertex represents a minimum.
Understanding opening direction is required for recognizing when the vertex represents a maximum.
Understanding constant terms is essential before students can find the y-intercept by setting x=0.
Students must understand inequality symbols before they can distinguish inequalities from equations.
Understanding inequality vs equation differences is prerequisite to grasping solution set concepts.
Understanding solution sets is essential before students can represent them on number lines.
Number line representation skills provide foundation for understanding interval notation.
Understanding basic addition/subtraction rules is essential before learning complete inequality manipulation rules.
Understanding positive multiplication/division rules is required before mastering all inequality rules.
Understanding negative multiplication/division rules is crucial for complete inequality manipulation mastery.
Complete inequality rules are prerequisite to solving even simple one-step inequalities.
One-step inequality solving provides the foundation for tackling two-step inequalities.
Two-step inequality skills are essential before handling complex multi-step linear inequalities.
Multi-step linear inequality skills provide foundation for compound inequalities.
